turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: May it please the Court.
This is an action involving the right of 1377 Negroes to be restored to the registration rolls of Washington Parish in Louisiana.
It is distinguishable from Raines in that Raines involved the question of their being placed upon the registration rolls in the State of Georgia.
In this case, the District Judge, in his decree, held that the action involved massive discrimination against these Negro voters.
The various acts that were involved resulted from challenges under the statute of Louisiana.
The statute of Louisiana provides for challenges in a certain manner and that is set out in a Government's brief.

The challenges maybe made by persons, voters who will swear out affidavits in regard to the discrepancy in a form that is described in the statute and it's exhibit here in our brief, in which this discrepancies are raised.
Then the Registrar acts upon those affidavits which are to be sworn out before the Registrar or his deputy.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: There's two affidavit as I understand (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: At least two voters.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- or not have been done by voters.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right Mr. Justice Whittaker.

In this case, if the record is clear, it's submitted that no examination of any ward in regard to whether voters were in compliance with the requirements of the registration laws was made where there were no Negro voters in that ward.
There were only 10 white voters' registrations, who were challenged in any way in Washington Parish in connection with this matter.

The record is clear that the Registrar who deals with these records day by day and continuously over a long period of years that he described, knew that over 50% of the registrations' records of the white voters in this parish had exactly the same kind of discrepancies that were found to be sufficient under these challenges to remove these colored voters from the registration rolls of this parish.
There were 1514, colored voters registered in that parish before this action occurred.
By this action, 1377 of those 1514 were removed from the rolls.
There are over 11,000 white, 11,444 to be exact, on the registration rolls in this parish and only 10 of them were challenged.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Excuse me?
Under this state procedure does the mere submission of the affidavit result in removal or is some determination statement?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The Registrar has to act but as a part of proceedings, it is shown at the Registrar here, Mr. Thomas, brought an action for declaratory judgment in which he said these people were harassing, interfering with the conduct of his office and that he wanted an adjudication as to whether or not he had to make these removals from the registration rolls and whether or not it would be a violation of the injunction outstanding against him from 1950 in which he was directed by a Federal District Court not to discriminate against any voters in the registration by reason of their race or color.

And in this proceeding, the state District Judge held that he -- his function was ministerial and that he had no discretion and that he was, as soon as the challenge was filed that he was to proceed to remove them from the rolls that was his duty.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Does that mean he must remove them from the rolls or does he have a discretion, after a challenge has been initiated by these two affidavits, send out a notice, then when the voter responds to make the determination for himself as to qualifications?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well yes, but if there was no response I think is a fair interpretation of the state judge's decision, then he had no discretion that it was his – then his duty.
Now, there is an affidavit provided for in the state law, state statutes, in which they can respond by getting three voters to swear on affidavit on their behalf.
This affidavit is a -- a limited form and it's provided that they are residents of the district in effect.

The Court held this affidavit in the form required by the Louisiana laws will be no answer to these particular discrepancies because the -- the Court said that they would have to swear out an affidavit in which they would say that these particular discrepancies did not appear or did not occur on the record.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now do I understand, I mean to get this point clear in my mind, that it has been held by some court down there, that in the (Inaudible) of response by the voter, you have thus been challenged, you used the affidavits in the statutory laws, the Registrar has no discretion to overrule the challenge, but must remove the voter from the rolls.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's my understanding of the judgment of the state court, Mr. Justice Whittaker.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And one more question --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: And -- and the issue is, I might add there issue was further raised by the Registrar whether this type of discrepancy was sufficient for them to be removed from the rolls.
Now the discrepancies involved here were misspelling, the miscalculation of the age and illegibility and in a few cases, there is one about whether or not he was registered in any ward.
Now, it's the problem about age is where many of them missed the age by one day.

The state Attorney General has said that is not a disqualification, but the state court judge said it was and the missed one day, depends upon whether you're going to calculate it by figuring in the day of the filing or you figure it out.
Now, that's one and then the question of misspelling.
It's a -- a very interesting exhibit attached in the Appendix to the Government's brief.

To show you just how this worked in the operation and what in a front it is to the people of Louisiana, including these voters and the American people to be saying that these Negro voters were disqualified in the voting process by reason of what happened here.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I just -- as a matter of curiosity Mr. Solicitor, did you say that there were 15,000 whites on the voting list?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: 11,000, just as a matter of curiosity, do you happen to know how many voted at the last election?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No, I don't, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It has nothing to do with the case, I was just curious.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Could I ask you one question and I won't interrupt you.
You mentioned the 1950 injunction that had been issued against this Registrar.
What Court was that issued --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That was the Federal District Court.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Was there a -- is that a cited case, was there an opinion written?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: There was a -- it's set out in the record here on pages 99 and 100.
The effective orders are on page 100 at the top of the page, the two paragraphs.
One is summarized, restrained from denying and refusing to register eligible Negro -- Negroes as electors in this very issue.
Solely, on account of raising color and the second one is an injunction against making any distinction based upon raising color and the registration of collectors in Washington Parish.
That was outstanding from the date by the same district judge at that time.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor, may I ask you one more question?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And I promise that would be all.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) -- is there any record -- as I understand the Registrar is the only respondent (Inaudible), is that right?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, because the time for appeal is not yet up for the other parties and they would have I think until March if in case they want to notice an appeal and at the time the Government's filing they had not noticed.
So, the only person who had noticed an appeal was the Registrar.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Can the Registrar be chargeable with the dissemination in – in any way in the filing of affidavit against the Negroes but not against the whites?
He had anything to do that?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, he has the duty to administer these registration rolls and if he, as he testified he knew that over 50% of the white had exactly the same condition.
He had a duty with regard to those whites as well as the colored, if he was going to administer these as being grounds for removing them from the rolls.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: That's why I was interested to know whether he had a discretion to deny the challenge?
He has apparently no power to initiate a challenge against anyone.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: There's no decision of that kind and I don't think that it would be a fair conclusion from the decision of the state court.
Apparently, he has the power to initiate on his own the -- if a certain person does not come in within the statutory requirement, that's his function.
So that he -- he has the power, I don't think it would be disputed here to have removed this 50% of the whites if he'd proceeded to do it.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Then -- then two affidavits (Inaudible) one challenge and not required?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, that is for --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- that can start the procedure whereby he then the Court said, has a ministerial duty to proceed to do it.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But somebody -- is there some other way to initiate that thing?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I think he has the power and duty as the Court said to carry out the statutes and he knew that this record showed that the same disabilities occurred on 50% of the whites.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: When is he making (Inaudible) about it, he might have (Inaudible) over here, the same discrepancies on Negroes and whites and affidavits were presented to him challenging the Negroes.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But no affidavits presented to him challenging the whites.
Now what can he do?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: He's not helpless because he has to take into account the Constitution of the United States and the Federal Law which is primary and supreme and controlling his action as long he's -- as you knows that the particular acts that he is act -- asked to do are in violation or discriminatory of his own knowledge then it's his duty under the law that's supreme not to carry it out.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Alright.
Then that should give him the right to overrule the challenge and refuse to remove the challenge of Negro voters, isn't it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, he would have the duty not to exercise that challenge.

It's the contention of the Government whenever it's discriminatory because that is prohibited by federal law and that's supreme, but I was trying to tell you what the state court had held was his duty in regard to these particular challenges ones they came to him.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Now, if you --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The second part of your answer to Justice Whittaker's question implied another way of answering would have been (Inaudible) decide to be more explicit, if you can disregards what you have said with the state court's ruling as to his ministerial duty, is that incorrect?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes Mr. Justice Frankfurter.
I think you're -- you're within --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, I just -- I just want to know if that's what that mean?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: You're right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's was earlier -- you told earlier to Justice Whittaker state law so far as declared by decision of a ruling court for him, if there were no federal questions, the state also says, he has a -- he has a ministerial duty, meaning that if a formality is satisfied, he must act.

What you're saying now, what -- what your answer to Justice Whittaker amount to is in the context that was you're talking about, you may disregard what is a directing decision of a state court, is that right?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: We think it's right within In re Neagle, that's -- where the two come into clash that the can follow his federal duty and proceeding in accordance for that law.
Now, if you will turn to exhibits on the Appendix 42 (a) and notice the photo stub there, you'll see that Mrs. Affoway Smith in the first one on the left hand side --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- of the Governments brief -- the Government -- I'm sorry, the Governments brief, page 42 (a), there's a photo stub that you unfold.
You'll notice Affoway Smith and the -- the registration application in Louisiana records the fact of what's their race or color is, they're supposed to put that down.

One of the things that they challenged them for and they've been removed from the rolls in -- in some of these matters for is the fact that they put down C or colored, instead of black or they put down Negro instead of black and that is the ground that they have exercised the challenge and said that doesn't comply with their statutory requirement.
That isn't true of this one, but I just want to point that out as in you are examining it.
Now, this woman missed the date of the note -- the time that she had lived by one day depending upon why do you include the date of the application?
Now she is a teacher as you'll note from the -- the blank there in the application blank.
Now, if you move down to the blank just below that, you'll find the one of Mrs. William A. Luis.
She is also a teacher and she happens to be a white teacher, but she can't spell what the State of Louisiana.
She's spelled it L.O.U.I.S.I.A.N.I.A., but nobody challenges her.

Nobody removes her from the rolls and when she fills in the blank, the name of the householder at the present address is, that should be her own name if that's who the householder is but she fills in 4632 Avenue G, which is a improper answer to the question the way they've been running and so she should have been challenged by anybody who was trying to be non-discriminatory and moved off the rolls, but there's the white sign there and of course you don't that.
Now, you go to the next page of the photostatic copy.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was there proof in the record that Mrs. Luis is a registration had been under scrutiny?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No.

There was proof that the Registrar worked for these records all the time and knew, but there was no proof that these particular members of the citizens' counsel, white citizen's counsel that filed his challenges had examined that --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, all I was wondering was the discrepancies which you point out here whether they were -- whether the record shows that they -- were might have been occasioned by overlooking each particular registrations or whether -- how these registrations were looked over and -- but not challenged.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.
Well, let me see if this will answer your questions Mr. Justice Harlan in this regard.

I -- squarely, I don't think there -- there wasn't any proof that this particular application was looked at except that it came during the trial, but the Registrar testified, admitted that 50% of these applications in his office, he knew to have the same discrepancies as those of the colored that he removed.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: That's not accused of?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That is -- that's admitted.

So, there's no question but he was aware now but he was aware now, whether he was aware of just Affoway Smith, I -- I wouldn't say for a moment but he was aware that -- that it was all through his record as to the whites and that would be some six better than 5,000 -- 5,500 that were -- that way with the white.
Now --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Are you also aware, being aware, what can he do, the Registrar?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Oh, he has the power to correct that situation.
He has difficult problems politically if he does, but he has the power to comply with these statutes, if these -- if that's what the statutes mean.
I think that question is not now before the court in a way this record is.

I don't think that this is a proper construction of these statutes to say that to miss the day of the time you are -- have lived by one day just because you don't whether the statutes means that you shall include the day of the application or not include it is a reasonable interpretation of this statute at all.
And I don't think if you misspelled Louisiana because you add an extra "I", well that should be have any relation to your fitness to be a voter in the state of Louisiana or on the other state.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) what clause did it use to (Inaudible) it disqualified as one (Inaudible) disqualified vote.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's what I'm saying and if the Registrar has the duty to abide these statutes, it's his function not only to act under challenges, but to act directly if these are real basic discrepancies that should control his right to be on the vote rolls.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It is also conceded or conceded by you the color question apart, suppose there were no color question, that the Registrar could not sua sponte on his own motion throw out Mrs. Louis's registration.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Oh, I claim he could.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Apart from any question of differentiation to the whites and colored people.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Oh, I -- I say these aren't enough if that's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- I say this type of discrepancy should not have any bearing under the law.
I don't think its constitutional to they have that kind of a measure of whether persons are qualified both.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, my --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I think it has no reasonable relationship with it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not sure I made my question clear.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose, there were no questions, no color discrimination there and suppose that Mrs. Luis had made -- had made an entry that in your point of view was egregious that it didn't come within the statute, color question, color discrimination apart in your view would the Registrar, could the Registrar on his own motive find her -- her registration disqualifying registration?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: In my view, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, he has that power and the duty and I think that was –

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Wholly apart from, I'm not talking on discrimination –

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: - under the Fourteenth or Fifteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Now on this next page of the photo stats, Mr. James D. Cyrus misspelled Pearl River which was the county, that's on page 42 (b) of the Government's brief and you'll note here is a Negro and he was challenged and removed from the list.
Then if you go there --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What -- what was his defect?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Pearl River.

He spelled, P.E.R.A.L transposed the R and the L and then if you go to the next one, Herman Manning you'll notice he -- the way he put his name in the first part there, he didn't spell it right at all.
He mixed up the Herman and the Manning so it's hardly possible to decide what he meant and then the when he put down his sex, he put down “F” for female, I guess for a man.
Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How would the Registrar know whether he was a man or not or a female, even though they might be, unless it might -- unless it is clear, but there are number of -- of names of Marian or Adrian or Vivian that do not disclose whether male or female.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I haven't heard of Herman not disclosed in the record.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Her name.
I -- I'll use that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right there's a circle around Mr. too, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.
I didn't see -- catch that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I didn't mean as to this particular one.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: General rules or -- how do you just -- how do you (Inaudible) Herman out of the word H.E.R.M.AN.N.I.N.G.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I'm trying to make it out in this signature Mr. Justice Frank -- Whittaker at the bottom down there.
You see, his got his signature down and then he let it put the name in up above, it's different.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Who encircled the Mr.?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I assume he did but I -- that isn't the evidence in proof.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is -- is it been challenged by the state, if I may speak of Thomas as a state the Attorney General is here I take it --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- is it challenged by the state that there were these numerous, identical or for all practical purposes are identical failures in spelling or in addition or substraction identification in white registrations as against colored, is that challenged here?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No Mr. Justice Frankfurter, that's admitted in the record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, apart from -- from making the case more vivid and concrete, you're -- you're not addressing yourself to something has been in issue, are you?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No.
What I'm --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not -- I'm not your -- your argument in this case, and I just want to know whether there's any context on what you're now developing?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I think it -- no, there is not to answer that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I think this illuminates --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- the kind of problem that we're dealing with in this area.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understood that that let's you know your position and I know that the counsel want to present the case to you.
I just want to know whether, whether the basic, the underlying factor in dispute here or the legal consequence or merely the legal consequences and the obligation of state official etc., etc.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No, they ‘re not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are the findings challenged?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I would think some of the -- the findings as to the conclusions, the Court made in regard to some of the facts as to –-

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Conclusions, the finding of the facts challenge?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, on some parts of that -- there -- there's no issue on the facts Mr. Justice Black.
On the –

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But there was finding, wasn't there?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, there were.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, you say the findings.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has there been any challenge to any particular part of those findings?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: They submitted findings of their own which were not the same as the Governments.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They were not accepted?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.
That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did -- did they find the points on this which they were hoping or on which they began, they appealed in the Court of Appeals?
There was some doctrine indicating what they are going up on, wasn't there?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, it was a in --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So the appeal is to question and determine.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- it was incomplete Mr. Justice Frankfurter as we say in our brief, because the notice to appeal had been filed but they had obtained a stay and so we argue points here in anticipation of positions that they might take.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, have they taken them in the brief?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: They have taken some in their brief.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: As to what --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The -- the factual situation it does not seem to be an issue between --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Does the brief challenge some other findings of facts?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Not as I recall.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, from the finding of fact, was Justice Black's question?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I haven't seen them.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: My recollection is the brief does not put an issue of these facts.
It puts an issue, the legal questions.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: There's one other thing before a proceedings to the legal arguments that I would like to call your attention to and that is, that by these tests which I want and I think you'll understand me but I want to make clear the Government does not think are valid constitutional tests anyway to apply these discrepancies in this manner, but they were applied in this discriminatory manner, but regardless of that, if you apply it as they did, and if you would apply them across the board to both colored and whites, this record demonstrates that you would eliminate 90% of the colored by this kind of discrepancy and 50% of the whites.
Now, they didn't do that, they only challenged 10% -- 10 of the whites.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: If you're right in the statements you've just made, this irregular, type of irregular argument was not the constitutional basis upon which the Registrar may expel them from the rolls then that ends your (Inaudible), doesn't it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, if you would conclude that.
Now that was not –

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I didn't say, I said assume we did --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That was not the basis of the decision below and you might not -- and you wouldn't reach that question if you found a discrimination contrary to the Constitution which was the basis of the lower court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If we found it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, if you found that he was, it is judgment to that effect was valid.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: The trial court's finding (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The trial courts finding--

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: For it's evidence.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right and they were fully supportive and much of it, there was no controversy about it at all.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In considering it do we have before us a permanent injunction or an interlocutory injunction?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: You have the permanent injunction.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The permanent injunction.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm a little (Inaudible) minute or two or two minutes, in some of the seven states surely, there are all white counties (Inaudible) somewhere in all black county.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, I don't know whether that's in Louisiana or not, but assume an all white county in Louisiana, assume that, and the rejection for the striking from the rolls was made on what has been nominated several times as unconstitutional criteria, a misspelling of -- of one's own name by -- or things like that or being wrong as this is (Inaudible) by a day.
Assume an white county, no discrimination but white vote was struck, was stricken, names of the white vote was stricken from the list.

Would there be any -- is there any constitutional – federal, is there any -- what is the law -- what -- on what basis if the Government or anybody else go in challenge state law and say, “You deprive me of my right to vote on this trivial misspelling,” is there?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Wouldn't the -- this test that the state has to apply about voting in regard to -- certainly in regard to federal elections have to be reasonably rate -- related to that franchise or that voting.
That's what I'm trying to point out and if --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you'll have to -- it would be a very the problem, I must say in this one.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The state might be very strict in its demand for literacy.

As of the present Congress could, tomorrow this afternoon if it shows, makes its own specific requirements as to federal -- as to the federal franchise, but until it has done so, the fact that the state is very strict and demands a high rate of literacy (Inaudible), I should think you would have a very different case that if you came here on that Mr. Solicitor?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, that is a different problem.
I do think it's important to -- in regard to literacy as the Court did in the Lastner case to keep in mind that if your literacy test is one that obviously is going to discriminate --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what I do solely, yes.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- on the basis of raise or color, then it's one that can't stand up against the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And what you answered a little while ago, I think to Justice Whittaker, if the same test of a -- of a failure to live up or a very fastidious standard would throw out the 10% of whites and 50% of Negroes, you also got a different problem there.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It's very --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I was thinking of -- of the intrinsic invalidity of a very high in my point of view, even exquisite standard of literacy or intelligence.
If it is (Inaudible) done, I think one would of the other tough job saying that's the deposition of your federal franchise.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: As long as it's really related to literacy, I wouldn't have any real problem about it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I thought your entire argument was based on the fact it is discriminating here on the basis of color?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right Mr. Justice Black.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That case is based in the findings?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I'm a little confused to what you said to Justice Black.

I thought this was a preliminary injunction as it's described in your brief rather than a permanent one, but if you look at the injunction, it has all the earmarks of being permanent, which is the fact?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I thought that it was a preliminary injunction originally and then they granted permanent.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Under the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible) there's a temporary injunction.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It's still a preliminary injunction.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: From your point of view, I should think you'd like to have a temporary injunction.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I don't see how you read it between those temporary.
However, as well as the record 153 and 154, (Inaudible) the Court is called on to take a further step, I don't think you (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I inquired about that from the man who tried the case and he thought it was a permanent injunction.
So, I think possibly it's the same difficulty that you Justices are having with it that it was a denominated preliminary, but in a form it was quite permanent.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: With this very jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

The reason I have dwelled upon this proposition of the discrepancy and the effect of this -- even this type of discrepancies or -- or defects in these applications was that this case presents to the Court the problem even if it has been administered fairly and without discrimination as far as applying the same test to the white as to the black, you would have a discrimination in effect because you would eliminate 50% by this test of the white as against 90% of the black.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Then you get back to as I understand your problem which is you have finding, saying this was done on the acaccount of color and -- and there is no challenge to it, but as I understand those findings that I see, that as I understand it you open this evidence to show that they're supported -- argument showed that they're supported by evidence? Do they claim they're not supported by evidence?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, we anticipated that they might make that claim in the way this case came up you see, because we didn't -- we weren't able to tell when the Court took case by -- at the time we filed out petitions and also our brief what their contentions were going to be.
So, we argued that as well as the rest and we have to do that because --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did they challenge the findings in the Court after they were made to the District Court?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I don't recall if they did Mr. Justice Black, but we did argue that they were fully supported by the evidence because the Court in taking the case here, although we won it below the Government did, the Court asked us if we wanted to -- to file a petition by a certain date.
So, although we have been the successful party below, we filed the petition for certiorari here and then we briefed it first without knowing fully what the other side was going to develop against us.
And so, we tried to anticipate all the arguments that would be open to the parties if they came and they tried to show that the findings in fact -- of fact and conclusions of law.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did they file one brief or two?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: They filed one.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: This brief?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.
And that was filed on Saturday, this last Saturday by the Court's order and we -- we examined it.
I'm not complaining about that at all, but I just wanted to show you how it lead us to the point where we had to develop our case and try to anticipate arguments as we did.
And so, we tried to show that the findings were fully justified and in much of the evidence it was admitted.
Now, to proceed to the question of law, we get to the question of whether this is state action.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Why -- why is that important?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Whether it's state action?
Well, the contention is made like in Raines that --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: In the -- you have a statute here that says -- subsection (b) in page 3 whether acting on the appellant law or other way.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Under subsection (b).
We are treating subsection (a) and (c).

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Well, (c) says that violation of (b) gives the Attorney General the right to institute an action.
If (b) is involved, well, I'm reading (c).

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I am wondering also if it wouldn't come under 80 U.S. Code, 241 conspiracy no more question for anything (Inaudible) so forth and it doesn't pre exercise the enjoyment of the right which been held Constitution.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- and most of the case.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: This case was brought by the Attorney General and it was under the power of this statute of the 1957 Civil Rights Act --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Under the power you -- you brought it under that statute.
Does that tie you down to any particular statute as far as the violation of law is concerned and conspiracy is concerned?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, it's conceived that the Attorney General's own action could be brought in -- under this particular statute for this type of violation.
Now, the conspiracy under 241 was a different problem as far as the Attorney General brings the action himself.
The -- there's no question but what individuals could bring certain actions under the civil rights statutes before them.

And Section (b) of this statute has been construed by the Government to cover the intimidation and the threatening and coercion or attempt to intimidate, threaten or coerce any other person, Mr. Justice Douglas, rather than dealing with this type of preventing or denying the right to vote.
See, it's -- deals with the intimidation and threatening and coerce or attempt for the process of interfering and so forth.
Now, we -- we treated this as being under subsection (a) and that the action could be brought under subsection (b) because it was not an intimidation or threatening.

It was actually the using of Governmental process as of the state to accomplish this discrimination and it was a state action because they -- they took advantage of what the statute provided for these affidavit challenges and then they submitted them, they swore to them and used the office of the Registrar in order to get all the information.
They swore to --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Who -- who used them?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, they were these persons that swore out the affidavit who were members of --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They were not the state officers, were they?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No.
They were members of the white citizens' council.

They swore out the affidavits that are provided for under this state statute and put into -- they triggered, initiated the state action and then that Registrar proceeded to act in accordance with their challenges, but they were the ones that triggered that state action and the statute itself contemplates that private individuals shall do that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If that's so, why do you talk about the state action (Inaudible) these private individuals?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, because it's against --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do you have to do it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It's a -- it's a panoply.
It's a combination.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I don't know what panoply means.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It's -- it's a --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand when you say that a person is not a state officer and the state is not to do it, but I don't quite understand your panoply.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, maybe I can clarify Mr. Justice Black that the persons who filed the affidavits started the action, but the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Private --private person.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- but they can't remove them from their rolls.
The Registrar has to do that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, what you're saying in -- isn't it that if a private persons joined with somebody else to take away these rights, these private persons are allowed whether they are acting for the state or not.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Black.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's what I thought.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The -- the only problem we have about a conspiracy is that the -- the evidence did not show that the Registrar conspired with these people.
He claimed they were interfering in this lawsuit with his operation and conduct of his office and therefore, that he want them to stop.
That's what he said anyway in the litigation.

And yet, he proceeded to do all of the things that they wanted to do and when they filed only 10 affidavits in regard to whites in the parish, he didn't say, “Well, what about all these others that I know about?” or, he didn't proceed to remove any of those, but he proceeded to carry out the discrimination that they had started.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, Mr. Solicitor General, I -- I'm just still concerned about that question.
Now, let's take Section 244 of record -- at the Louisiana's brief, 122.

Now, let me -- this says, “Whenever the Registrar has reason to believe that any name on the registration record has been illegally or fraudulently placed there then he may ask,” on the next Section of -- at this brief, page 125, Section 245 says, “Upon a written affidavit signed and sworn to unduplicated before and filed with the Registrar his deputy by two bona fide voter -- registered voters, he must act.”
Now, suppose that the Registrar under Section 244 does not believe these irregularities make the registration illegal, he therefore doesn't ask.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, he --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But -- but under -- but -- but under 245, affidavits are filed, and then you tell us that he must act and that he has no discretion even to find against the challenge.
Is that what you want us to understand?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, if you're going to apply the state law and disregard his federal duty, we say that the federal duty doesn't permit him to act as either one.
But brushing that aside, the state court said that these were persons with these discrepancies were illegally on the rolls.
So, he comes right within their Section 244 because he testified, he admitted it, that he knew that 50% of them have those and he handled these records everyday.
So, he knew that 50% were illegally on the rolls of the white persons and it was his duty under that section of the statute, if you disregard his federal duty not to discriminate to remove them.
It's clear.
Now, he said that he didn't think these were enough and so he went to the state court and asked and the state court said that it was enough.
The power is certainly granted to him by that Section.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, only if he believes that he has reason to believe, then he being convinced may act, but under 245 that the affidavits he'd filed, he must act.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now then, is it true that he has no discretion under 245 to sustain the registration and overrule the challenge?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, the -- the court held -- the state court held that he had no discretion that it was a ministerial act.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But if that violated the supreme federal rights, but of course he did (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And that's --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: And that's what we claim was his legal duty and it overrides and it was the supreme duty and therefore, he had no right to do it.
We say he had no right to do it, because it was discriminatory.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: That was added up for me.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I was going to say as far as we're concerned, the defendant's duty, the Registrar's duty as measured by the state supreme -- by the state law is what this Court said it was his duty, that's how we have to take the law.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.
As far as the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: As a state law duty

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- state court --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- Duty.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.
Then I think you put a --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But we don't have to worry --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- clause on that.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: We don't have to worry about how we read the statute.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, that -- that's my interpretation Mr. Justice Harlan and then I think you put gloss of the federal law as to determine what's supreme.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I'm talking about the state law.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

And he had the power according to the state court's interpretation to act on his own under the first section and -- well, the Court told him, "These were enough" so he had no discretion Mr. Justice Whittaker once he was told that he by -- by the Court that this was enough as far as the state court law was concerned, that section -- the statute gave him the power to act --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black

Of course, I'm sure -- if it apprises this Court of the wording of the Fifteenth Amendment wherein it merely denies the -- the United States or any of the states from abridging the rights of persons to vote because of their color.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins

This Court, I'm sure is a (Inaudible) very many decisions wherein it's been said that the question of qualifications of voters is strictly within the states itself and this -- this matter incidentally does concern state elections.

The election is coming up on the 9th -- April 19th, 1960 where it seems that this necessity for reinstating these people back on the road is a state election and no federal official being involved in this particular election.

turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I see if I understand you Mr. Attorney General, otherwise -- well, otherwise qualified, it can't mean can it that the state court may disqualify them and therefore, there's a state determine this qualification and therefore they're not citizens or otherwise qualified.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, but the very -- the very issue of whether or not, this is all argumentative (Inaudible) is this --

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Yes.
I understand.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If the claim is that the disqualification itself is a violation of federal law, then that can't be determined by the state court so as to prevent it being examined in the federal court that to be -- has to be Attorney General under 1957 Act, would it?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
