turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: And likewise, I would like to mention to the Court that this mere challenging, the mere issuance of a challenge, the affidavit of challenge does not disqualify a person in Louisiana from voting.

And that I think is a basic issue here which the contention of our argument that this Court lack jurisdiction because this suit is brought on a basis of challenges which were issued to these various points.
When the affidavit of challenge is made in the State of Louisiana, the -- the Registrar of Voter -- Voters as mentioned as much my Solicitor General has no discretion in the matter.
He must as a mandatory ministerial act accept the said challenge.
The person who is challenged receives from him within the -- within two days, a citation in which citation is stated the cause of challenge, the cause of challenge is sent to this man.
He has 10 days after receiving the citation to come in and attempt to traverse the challenge made.
If he does successfully do so, he remains on the rose as a Registrar of Voter and he then yet has a right to vote.

If he self-excludes himself by not answering the challenge within the 10 days, and I say to this Court that he is the man who had denied himself of the right to vote and not the man who filed the affidavit.
He had disqualified himself from voting by not having answered the challenge.

Again, at the end of the 10 days, if he has not answered this challenge, the Registrar of Voters again has a mandatory duty, not a discretionary duty, a mandatory duty to expunge him from the rose of registered voters.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you this --

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- in this connection?
I -- I'm interested in your discussion.
It seems to me like your problem here is this.
The supreme law as you said that you cannot do this on the account of color.
You had a finding that it was done on the acaccount of color.
So, you don't claim that the state can bar him on the acaccount of color, these people on a acaccount of color --

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: We said the state could not bar him on a account of color.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It cannot be.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If you can get down, do you not to the question of whether the finding was right in this case.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That's correct.
I would get to the point that the -- whether he was qualified or not is the real issue, not his color.
There is no --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But, but not whether he's qualified, but whether he's -- whether you have put him out of voting because of his color.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That is the issue.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't see were all these others have much to do with it because the sole issue here, have they been put off because of color.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Well, I would say the sole issue is does he have a right to come into the federal courts claiming abridgment of a constitutional right.
Let's assume for argument sake that one did -- an individual citizen did want to -- did want to challenge him because of his color.
The mere fact that this individual challenged him would not give the United States a cause of action against that individual.
Maybe the individual might have been discriminatory in his -- in his theory or in his motivating cause for challenging.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What difference does it make about why it was done?
The issue here is, under the findings that I see, solely whether these people have been barred from voting in the State of Louisiana on a account of color.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Well, I say by the state, if it please the Court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, if the Registrar did it, that's the state, isn't it?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Yes, I would say that the Registrar had the mandatory duty but he did not --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, he don't have a mandatory --

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: He did not discriminate.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He doesn't have a mandatory duty, does it, if -- if it's on the account of color?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Well, he has --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Can the state allow him to say that it's mandatory on you to remove this man because of color?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I think not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, do you do not file to get back to the one issue that you have to meet?
I don't see you can meet it.
Have they -- does the record show that these people, the findings that were made that there were barred on account of color is supported by evidence?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I think not, Your Honor.
It's absolutely --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: -- no evidence to that -- to that effect.

Each challenge issued has its various defects which lend to the literacy and to the qualification of these parties which would lend to a fact as to whether or not this Court has jurisdiction, to whether or not they're entitled to come in or the United States Attorney General is entitled to come under the Civil Rights Act under -- under Section C which gives him that entitlement when interstate action barring a party from discriminating against his people solely on because of race, color, or previous condition of servitude.
To get to the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you need by ask some questions in order to bring out the fact of the whole electoral process down there that is as I understand it.
As I understand from the decree of Judge Rice 3 (b) he says there, he must permit the names to remain all for present and current roles or qualified voters.
That means they're off the rolls.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, what is the relation between being off the rolls and having the right to vote?
Can you vote if you're off the rolls?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: You may not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You may not.
After they've been put off the rolls which is indispensable to the exercise to the franchise.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And as Justice Black has indicated, the -- the findings of facts are that they are off the roll because they were taken off and they were taken off because of they were colored.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I do not agree with the statement but --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, isn't that Judge Wright found?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Judge Wright found we claim that the findings of fact or in error for the reason that the -- they were not taking-- taken off the rolls because they were colored, they were taken off the rolls because they did not respond to the challenges issued.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes and the -- and the -- they didn't respond to the challenges issued because from their point of view, a colored man who did this doesn't -- doesn't qualify whereas a white man does and that's what I call discrimination if it's true.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I think that it's not true if it please the Court --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, then you are really addressing yourself.

You don't stop as Justice Black started in this question, namely there were findings of the facts that they were taken off the rolls, because they were colored people although the reason given was, that they didn't spell the name right or put an extra I or didn't cross the thing, but you say that you don't accept those findings as the starting point for legal discussion.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That's correct, I do not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I said the basis -- the basis of the challenges issued herein were because of the lack of the failure of these parties to pass intelligence test, the -- in the literacy test as prescribed by the state laws for qualification.
I should like to show -- read to you a couple of the applications keeping in mind that these applications were photostated by and at the request of United States Government.
They form a part of this record.

However, by stipulation between counsel, they have not been printed in the record but these are the identical copies which were furnished to us by the Attorney General -- the United States Attorney General's office.
We have here one from Miss Mamie Myles.
Of course, she spells Louisiana in outlandish way also, L-O-U-I-S-I-A-N-A.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How does she spell it, I'm curious.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: L-O-U-I-S-I-A-N-N-A-S, she has Washington spelled, W-A-S-G-T-O-N in answers the question, I have recite in the state since “all my lift “ L-I-F-T.
In the parish continuously all lift, L-I-F-T.
My -- my color is black, my -- my sex is female, F-E-L-M-E-L.
I now, affiliate with the Democratic party D-E-N-C-R-A-T-T party.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. -- Mr. Cousins, I'm interested to know, could the Registrar as matter of right have refused to sustain challenges on those particular persons, to those particular reasons?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: If he followed the Louisiana law, he may not incidentally.
I think it's important to the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He has a description doesn't he?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Yes, and he may not -- he may not --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He may not?
I thought all the Registrars in the southern states have a wide discretion.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: To refuse a challenge?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: To -- to refuse --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Or the man can vote.
I'm not --

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I'm sorry Mr. Justice Black.
I think Mr. Justice Whittaker's --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: We're talking about the same thing -- we are talking about the same thing --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Same thing to reject to -- to overrule the challenge even though these spelling errors appear may been presented by the affidavit signed by two voters challenging the voter, the voter comes in and he says, “Yes, I admit that I made these spelling errors,” does the Registrars do have power to leave him on the rolls?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I would say he has a duty to remove him if this -- if the --if the -- have power affidavits to traverse the challenge do not successfully traverse the challenge.
However --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: it can't -- he can't by counter affidavits correct the spelling on the registration card --

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Because the Registrar of Voters could have an idea that the -- this word spelled the way that the Registrar had spelled it.

In which case, of course the challenged party would take the Registrar to quote or to Court on their mandamus and have the local court -- the state court decide who was correct, the Registrar and the registrant or the challengers.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But he knew how to spell Louisiana if your Registrar in -- in one of these counsels on these parishes himself spells it correctly and he looks at the --at the -- he looks at the registration and see that was spelled incorrectly, it has extra N now what not.

Do I understand you when you say that that's sustained of challenge because automatically Louisiana is misspelled and it was challenged because he misspelled and therefore you'll remove them from the roll, is that your view?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Well, Your Honor if it please, I think you would be violating his own knowledge about the matter.
Surely, he could do it in confines of his office but his office requires him to let only registered voters on the rolls.
He may even --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) -- and even in his spelling, you said -- I'm asking I am not --

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If he -- does it challenged because of a misspelling.
Louisiana is misspelled as we've seen it and if -- if the challenge is to the correctness of the spelling and the Registrar in good conscience and simply reading says, yes it is misspelled.
Is he under duty to sustain that challenge?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I would say he would be under duty -- to sustain that challenge.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose he knew the man, known him many years and he was a fine, high class, good citizen, wasn't well educated but he's a good citizen, everybody liked him.
You say that he would have to remove him from the roll, because he's misspelled the words?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Your Honor, I would say that if he had not --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would you say that?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Yes, I would if he has not (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Under the law of Louisiana?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I beg pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Under the law of Louisiana?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: If he was challenged.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If he was challenge because he misspelled one word.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I would say that he has not met the literacy test.
Now, of course we do have a system of where illiterates may vote under Louisiana law where they don't have to fill out these cards.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about this gentleman named Mr. Herman somebody?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He's a man I am told.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I beg pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Mr. Herman is a man, did you look at his?
Did -- was it right to let him vote?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Yes.
If Your Honor please, that would be under the discretion of the Registrar --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: -- whether or not he want --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why would it be in the discretion?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Whether he wanted to file -- there is no -- I agree with you that there is no definite standards for that as far as I know is to--

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That is right.
You submit, it's always this way I think I know it.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It's the law which gave the Registrar the very wide broad discretion looking at the man, looking at his education and knowing his -- his standing in the community and so forth to take him or not him as he saw fit.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: You Honor, if may it please, I think if he does that he is not doing his duty under the law.
I think there are certain standards have been set by various decisions of the courts as to whether or not --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, one other answer is that he must not misspell a single word.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: If Your Honor please I don't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I didn't, I said there are many standards which have been set by the other Court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose you misspelled six words, he's a good citizen, everybody knows it, a good man in the community, high standard, he's a reputable man, is it your idea that a Registrar has to remove him from the roll?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I would say that would be strictly within the prerogative of the Registrar whether or not he is going to carry out his duty if it may please the Court.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- prerogatives, you mean discretion or duty?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I would say he has a duty to see whether or not a person who registers has met the minimum literacy test of the state.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: You're speaking under Section 244 now, that's under Section 244?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: 244, I think it's a kind of challenge.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: All right, now, let's go to 245 --

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: -- if it please the Court.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- which is Mr. Justice Black situation where the man is presented the affidavit, two affidavits have been presented against him, saying he misspelled the word -- the word Louisiana, he has 10 days within which to rejoin, doesn't he?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: He comes in but he cannot correct the misspelling of Louisiana in the original registration challenge.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now then, answering Mr. Justice Black's question quite specifically has the Registrar any power to leave him on the roll or must he strike him off?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I thought I answer that before by saying he has the power to leave on the rolls.
However again, the challenger has the power to take him into Court and let the Court determine whether or not this applicant has met the standards.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- you -- I thought I understood you -- I thought I understood you when you said that if a challenge is made to a fellow who is on the rolls, on the ground that he doesn't need a literacy test and the Registrar finds that in fact, the -- the challenged voter has misspelled.
I thought I understood you but you said, if he's performing his duty he must accept that challenge as sustained.
Did I misunderstand?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Your Honor, of course, you're placing me in the position here of trying to determine what each Registrar around the State of Louisiana would do --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, I'm asking you what your conception is under the law of the duty of the Registrar not whether he wants to wink an eye but -- but does he under the law may do what Judge -- Justice Black suggested?

The fellow has made eight misspellings but the Registrar knows him, he make a good citizen and he's an honorable man and all the rest, has he -- that much leeway to decide whether it comes within the statute.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Your Honor here has no more leeway than the courts would allow him if he allowed this --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But if you're right about that, then it's repeating the thing over -- did I understood you a little while ago?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, Mr. Cousins, may I -- may I put it in just little -- little different way.
If the challenge is made, is it anything more than a mere ministerial duty on the part of the Registrar to remove it?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: He -- if that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is it a ministerial duty of his to then remove it?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: The only time when a minimum amount of discretion would come in on the part of the Registrar is the situation as Justice Frankfurter and Justice Whittaker have mentioned that when an attempt is made to traverse a challenge made then, there would be a certain play of discretion on the part of the Registrar.

However, that -- that discretion of his would again be controlled by a decision of the court in case this -- in the effect, either the challenger or the challenge would take him to test into the state courts.
His only discretion would lie as again I repeat when affidavits to traverse the challenge are brought in.
Other than that, he has no discretion.
He must accept the affidavits.
If the parties do not come in within the 10 days prescribed, he must mandatorily expunge these people from the registration rolls.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well the, but -- but how -- please tell me I don't understand how would I go about traversing by an affidavit, a misspelled word in the registration certificate?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Your Honor if it please, it's -- it's conceivable that the person who made the challenge was in error in making the challenge on the misspelled word.

Again like the age here is quite conceivable at the person who challenged on the basis of age was wrong in the challenge, and if a party who was challenged could bring an affidavit to prove that they were correct and the challenger was in error, then certainly they'd be entitled to remain on the rolls.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, take the -- take the exhibit if the Government (Inaudible) his brief on page -- open at page 42.
Mr. Cousins and if does A do not computed correctly on application, age do not considered correctly on application, well that's a -- that's an arithmetic calculation, isn't it?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, and so, no affidavit as Justice Whittaker suggested could -- could change that correct challenge if that would be a correct challenge, could it?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I would say that it is conceivable that it could, if it please Justice Frankfurter for the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But just as you give (Inaudible) would you?

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: I would say that this man who has been challenged could file three counter affidavits of persons who would calculate the age the way this Registrar has calculated.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean, calculate erroneously and say that the division as to arithmetic was carried.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Your Honor, Mr. Justice Frankfurter if it please the Court, this is an allegation by a challenger.
This is not the decision of the Registrar.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Oh, but he --

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: This is not the decision of the Registrar.
This is the an -- this is the opinion of the challenger.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But wouldn't the correctness or error of his claim be something to be verified or discredited by just looking at the dates he gives.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: Well, that's correct.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And if that charges is sustained age not computed correctly, all sorts people make mistakes, I believe half of the human race if half the human race (Inaudible) make mistakes in calculating their ages.

turn.speaker: weldon_a_cousins
turn.label: Mr. Weldon A. Cousins
turn.text: That is correct if it pleases the Court, but that would not be a question for this Registrar to decide.
He would merely try to ascertain the correctness of the traversing affidavits which were presented by the present challenge.
This is --

section.heading: Argument of Henry J. Roberts, Jr.

turn.speaker: henry_j_roberts_jr

turn.text: -- and the Associate Justice if could take just a little bit of a time to see if I could explain exactly the situation we have here to see if I can bring this Article 245 into focus as to exactly how did they use in this instance.

For instance, under the Louisiana registration system, the talk today on 245 is a challenging system opposed to the fact that these registered voters at one time had been a member of voting society because they were illegally placed upon the rolls.
Now reason why we say that is that under the constitution of Louisiana, we have a specific requirement as to be a registered voter.

The constitution which is set out in our brief says, that you must be at least 21, you must live in the State of Louisiana or locale for certain amount of time and more importantly, you must be a registered voter.
Now, by being a registered voter, you must obey the requirements set out is both the constitution and in the legislative acts.

Now, as this situation is presently developed, what has happen here in Washington Parish is that these people originally, whenever qualified, they should never have been placed upon the rolls, whether they be white or whether they be black because under Louisiana law, under the constitution, the filling of the registration blank itself is a literacy test.
Now, if you fail to pass the literacy test, that is the only time, the only time that the Registrar has any discretion.
He has no discretion whatsoever under 245.

Under 245 two registered voters come in and they say that they want to challenge me because I have done something wrong, I have misspelled a word, the registrar must -- under the Louisiana law, issue that challenge.
He sends that challenge to me and it's up to me to get three registered voters to come in and attempt to traverse that affidavit.

You ask me how I will traverse it, supposing I spelled the name of Louisiana wrong, suppose and I spell it L-U-Z-I-A-N-A and suppose I bring three registered voters with me who think that I have spelled Louisiana right who tell me, “I agree, that's the way you spell Louisiana, L-U-Z-I-A-N-A” and my Registrar at that time has no discretion.
He has to accept the fact that you spell Louisiana, L-U-Z-I-A-N-A.

turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Even though you do not?

turn.speaker: henry_j_roberts_jr
turn.label: Mr. Henry J. Roberts, Jr.
